data.title: dont miss the chandelier and full sized glass bust
data.text: These were the most striking pieces in the collection to me.  The full sized glass bust of a headless woman in aa gown has to be seen to be believed.  The Chihuli chandelier is most impressive also.  The general collection is interesting, historical, and behind plexiglass for the most part.  Very educational.

data.title: A fascinating place to observe artistry at work.
data.text: Be sure you check out the glassblowing and manipulation in the hot studio. Stay and tour the galleries to marvel at the fantastic skills involved in these pieces. Save some time for the main museum too.

data.title: Glass making demo
data.text: Stopped inside the pavilion after visiting the museum across the street and was able to see a glass blowing demonstration.  WOW.  Very informative and interesting.  They offer classes, too bad I don't live in the area, I'd like to sign up.  Definitely worth the trip.

data.title: Impressive Collection
data.text: Spacious pavilion which allows for a very nice presentation of glass.  Easy to view the great collection.  Displays are on one level which made it easy for my 90 year old mother-in-law to move around with her walker and see everything. Parking was the only fee and it is only $5.

data.title: Amazing glass!
data.text:
Most of us take glass for granted.  Whether is is keeping out the cold on our house or the wind off our face in a car, we think nothing of it.  The Glass Pavilion walks you through the evolution of glass from ancient times through modern art.  There are examples of 6,000 year old glass bowls (which look a lot like a modern bowl) and the most intricate modern glass pieces of art - plus everything in between.  

Walking through the various exhibits, it is easy to wonder why a particular glass has been put on display.   Some of them are not all that dissimilar to ones in my own kitchen cabinet.  You just have to keep in mind that the glass on display was made by hand several hundred years ago, long before modern manufacturing and technology made the creation simple.

The history of the city of Toledo is intrinsically tied to the production of glass.  The museum was founded by and is still endowed by the biggest family names in the world of glass. As a result, this museum also reflects in great part the development of Toledo as well.

When looking through the galleries make sure you take the age of the glass into consideration as well.  How some of the pieces were created as long ago as they were is a true marvel!

Oh - and it is all FREE to visit!

How can you go wrong?

data.title: Great Museum
data.text:
The Glass Pavilion at the Toledo Museum of Art is exceptional. The building, located across the street from the Museum, is sleek and contemporary. The Glass Pavilion features works from ancient times up through the emergence of the Studio Glass movement to the present. 

The Museum and the Glass Pavilion are free, though parking costs $5.

data.title: Glass Sculpting
data.text: I've been here for 2 classes. The staff is wonderful, clear instructions & options are given, & you can fully participate! The only hold your hand if you'd prefer it. Skill level isn't an issue. I would definitely recommend this to anyone!

data.title: Not to be missed!
data.text: The Toledo Museum of Art is a wonderful place to visit.  We have been to museums all over the world and Toledo's is right up there with the great ones.  The Glass Pavilion is all about "glass" since Toledo was once known as "The Glass Capital" of the world.  The exhibits are wonderful and displayed in the best way to view.  Not to be missed is the famous "Libbey Glass Punch Bowl" and cups, and newly returned ladle.  The glass blowing is amazing to watch and very informative.  The exterior and grounds of the museum are worth a leisurely walk to experience the many works of art displayed in the Sculpture Garden.

data.title: Interesting glass pieces, beautiful building
data.text: The Glass Pavilion is a part of the Toledo Art Museum. It is a lovely, light-filled building with (appropriately) large glass windows.  The exhibits were arranged chronologically and we found the ancient glass particularly fascinating.  Also loved the "over the top" cut-glass pieces.  Some of the modern glass art was interesting. We watched a glass-making demonstration for a short while.  This museum is well worth visiting.  There is no charge for admission. The parking was a little expensive, $5.

data.title: Interesting part of the Toledo Museum of Art
data.text:
The Glass Museum is part of the Toledo Museum of Art, a separate building across the street from the main building.  Lots of interesting pieces as well as sculpture on the grounds.  In one of the rooms of the gallery, toward the back, is a separate room of pieces not officially on display.  These are on racks and are also interesting to browse through.  Something not seen so often in galleries.  On the premises is an area where glassblowing demonstrations take place.  Craftsman will make one piece as a demonstration, narrating the process.  Seating for this is not elevated, so if you have children who will not be able to see over adults, go early for front row.  The building itself should be considered part of the exhibit.  Even if you don't biologically need to, stop in the restroom (just said "building itself should be ...").

Can easily wander through the exhibits in an hour; add time for glassblowing if doing that, too, and add time if going to study pieces in detail.

The entire Toledo Museum of Art, including the Glass Pavilion, is free.  Parking is $5 and, once parked, there is no need to "move" -- just walk directly across the street.

Unless pressed for time, no reason to visit Museum of Art and not include Glass while in The Glass City.

data.title: Interesting unexpected find in Toledo
data.text:
We were meeting friends for lunch and decided to stop by the Pavilion which is part of the Toledo Museum.  What a nice surprise!  Admission is free although there is a $5 parking fee.
Exhibits are well done with plenty space for people to wander around.  Interesting pieces from all areas and time periods.  We caught the end of a live demonstration of glass blowing.  The demonstrator was very knowledgeable and open to questions.
Nice experience.

data.title: Present and Past "Blown" Together
data.text: Quite a history of human culture by touring the pavilion. Century ago beautiful and utilitarian objects were created. Through the ages, many pieces were formed for artistic endeavors. Don't miss out on viewing a glass blowing demonstration. Recommend for all ages to share.

data.title: An Architectural Wonder
data.text: Imaging a building architecturally and structurally glass.  This is it.  Housing a wonderful collection of modern and antiquity glass, it's a fantastic and free part of the Toledo Museum of  Art.  Try your hand at glassmaking with one of their 3 hour classes, or drop in for wine tastings as part of "It's Friday!".  Great stop.

data.title: An Amazing Display of Glass Artistry with Live Demonstations
data.text: This is truly an enjoyable place to visit.  The glass artistry is dazzling and on certain days there are live demonstrations of glass blowing and creation of beautiful glass pieces.  It is well worth an afternoon to visit this museum and take in the art museum directly across the stree.

data.title: Nice little glass museum
data.text: We originally intended to see the main art museum, but we came in here by mistake and it was so close to closing that it made no sense to go over to the other museum. In fact, we had about 15-20 minutes and as a result, they were nice enough not to charge us the admission fee. We pretty much ran through and I believe we saw most of it. While not world class, it was fine and had some very pretty and novel pieces. Also, a decent collection showing the history of glass proved interesting. I am glad we got there in time to get in. I hope next time we are in Toledo we get to see the main museum. It looks like it would be quite good.

data.title: Just across from the main Museum
data.text: We love the glass art on display! Always worth the time to visit across the street from the main Museum

data.title: Wonderful Colours make this a thrill for adults and kids
data.text:
Who doesn't just love beautiful colours in glass?  I am surprised that there are only 8 reviews on this site.  My wife and two daughters, (Ages 7 + 10) absolutely loved this place.  First, we had a very informative 40 minute demonstration on glass blowing and the history of glass in general, and specifically in Toledo which appears to have a long history of glass making.

Make note that this is a part of the Toledo Museum of Art - so perhaps many people have left review there for the Glass Pavilion.

At any rate, after the top-notch demonstration, we had some time left to look around at both the amazing Glass House that everything sits in, and the exhibits.  The building is so cool with its massive piece of glass making up all of the outside and interior walls. The exhibits range from the ancient world up to the current century.  Very impressive and also so very beautiful.

I strongly recommend visiting this place.

data.title: Spectacular glass art.....spectacular glassblowing demo!!
data.text: Came here as our last visit we ran out of time to stop.  Really love the Chihuly chandelier, the cone and the huge crystal table and the crystal vases.  Most everything is behind cases but you can take pics!  Be sure to watch the demonstrations...very informative and interesting. Everything is on one floor so easy to get around.  They have a gift shop/cafe but most of the glass souvenirs are $25-75. Not sure about the books.  You can take classes that range in length and blowing activity from $20-100.  Def'ly a must see!  Everyone there is super friendly.  This place is free just like across the street at the Art Museum.

data.title: Great Demo
data.text: My wife wanted to visit the Toledo Museum of Art.  It was good and like any other art museum.  But I really enjoyed the free demonstration of glass blowing in the Glass Pavilion.  This along with glass art museum was well worth the visit.

data.title: Pretty neat...
data.text: ...to see pieces of glass art being created right before your eyes. The artists are very entertaining too, making the demonstration very interesting and keeping everyone's attention.  And their skill is awesome!
